conclusion: Consider the geometry of the semicircular glass brick and light ray propagation.
Light strikes the flat base at an angle \(\pi - \gamma\) relative to the horizontal plane.
Refraction occurs at the base, and rays travel through the glass brick towards the curved surface.
At the curved surface, light can pass through or undergo total internal reflection.
Critical angle for total internal reflection is \(\gamma\).
Light incident at angles greater than \(\gamma\) will be totally internally reflected.
Rays tangent to the curved surface at point \(E\) will not undergo total internal reflection.
Consider the center of the semicircle as point \(O\) with radius \(R\).
Point \(E\) is where the tangent ray grazes the surface.
Rays passing through the base without internal reflection have a maximum deviation angle of \(\gamma\).
Coordinates of point \(E\) can be found using semicircle geometry and angle \(\gamma\).
Angle between the normal to the surface at \(E\) and the incident ray is \(\gamma\).
Using trigonometry, find the horizontal distance from center \(O\) to point \(E\).
Width of the base portion is the horizontal distance from \(O\) to \(E\) and its symmetric counterpart.
